topic.name: Environmental Stewardship & Creation Care
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Environmental Stewardship & Creation Care in Geography

objectives.objective_text: Identify different kinds of animals.
Name Noah as the first person to save animals.
Identify that the world belongs to God.
Name ourselves as God's helpers.
Identify farmers taking care of the soil.
Name forests as places for animals.
Identify sun and wind as things that don't run out.
Name oil and coal as things we dig up.
Identify that we shouldn't take more than we need.
Name sharing as a good way to live.
Identify water as precious.
Name ways we use water (drinking, washing).
Recall that God made every animal special.
Observe that some animals are in danger.
Recall that we should keep the world clean for God.
Observe beauty as a gift from God.
Recall that trees help the earth.
Observe that plants need good dirt.
Recall that we should use things wisely.
Observe solar panels or windmills.
Recall that God gives us everything.
Observe that some people don't have enough.
Recall that we shouldn't make water dirty.
Observe rain catching in a barrel.
Defend access to water as a basic human necessity.
Summarize what 'Biodiversity' means (many kinds of life).
Explain why extinction is sad.
Explain the value of ecosystems beyond human use.
Defend the intrinsic value of creation distinct from utility.
Summarize the Christian duty to care for creation.
Explain that we worship the Creator, not the creation.
Explain the mandate to 'tend and keep'.
Defend a hopeful eschatology against nihilistic climate anxiety.
Summarize why soil is important for food.
Explain erosion (wind/water moving dirt).
Explain sustainable forestry practices.
Defend the biblical mandate to 'keep' the garden.
Summarize the difference between renewable and finite resources.
Explain how we use fossil fuels.
Explain the stewardship of the earth's mineral wealth.
Defend the responsible use of non-renewable resources.
Summarize the tension between using land and saving land.
Explain 'Sustainability' (using without using up).
Explain the role of technology in solving resource problems.
Defend the rights of future generations to resources.
Summarize the importance of clean drinking water.
Explain how pollution hurts rivers and oceans.
Explain the water cycle's vulnerability.
Compare a zoo with the wild.
Apply care for God's creatures.
Analyze the role of keystone species.
Interpret the command to be stewards of the animals.
Connect habitat loss to species decline.
Compare hope for a new earth with fear of the end.
Apply stewardship to daily choices.
Analyze the difference between Stewardship and Radical Environmentalism.
Interpret Romans 8:19-22 (Creation groaning).
Connect environmental care to love for the poor (who suffer most from pollution).
Compare healthy land with desertification.
Apply the idea of crop rotation (giving land a rest).
Analyze the causes of deforestation.
Interpret the Sabbath Year for the land (Leviticus 25).
Connect soil health to human health.
Compare clean energy with dirty energy.
Apply the idea of not wasting electricity.
Analyze the pros and cons of different energy sources.
Interpret the concept of 'Peak Oil'.
Connect energy use to economic development.
Compare conservation (wise use) with preservation (no use).
Apply fairness to how we share water and food.
Analyze the balance between economic growth and environmental protection.
Interpret the 'Tragedy of the Commons'.
Connect resource scarcity to conflict.
Compare water abundance with water scarcity.
Apply water-saving habits at home.
Analyze the global water crisis.
Interpret the 'Water Footprint' of products.
Connect pollution control to loving our neighbor downstream.
Evaluate the ethics of de-extinction or genetic modification.
Evaluate current climate policies through a Christian lens.
Evaluate the trade-offs of urban sprawl vs. agricultural land.
Evaluate the geopolitical implications of energy transition.
Evaluate the impact of consumerism on resource depletion.
Evaluate the privatization of water resources.
Construct an argument for species conservation based on God's glory.
Synthesize the psalmists' call for all creation to praise the Lord.
Construct a biblical theology of creation care.
Synthesize the gospel's implications for the physical world.
Construct a plan for preventing soil degradation.
Synthesize land management with food security.
Construct an energy strategy for a sustainable future.
Synthesize the moral imperative to provide energy for the poor.
Construct an ethical framework for resource extraction.
Synthesize biblical wisdom with modern resource management.
Construct a proposal for water conservation in a drought zone.
Synthesize the spiritual symbolism of 'Living Water' with physical thirst.
